Lauren Tuck
Sasha and Malia Obama Wore $20K Dresses to the Canada State Dinner
==================================================================
Lauren Tuck
·News Editor
March 11, 2016 at 9:03 AM
Link Copied
!
_Malia Obama wearing a strapless gown at the state dinner. (Photo: Getty Images)_
For the first time since being elected,  visited the United States. The “quite good-looking Canadian delegation” was welcomed to Washington, D.C., by President Obama and his family with a . But the event wasn’t just a first for Trudeau — Sasha and Malia Obama made their state-dinner debut as well.
“When I was first elected to this office, Malia was just 10 and Sasha was 7. And they grow up too fast,” the president said during his opening remarks at the event on Thursday night. “Now . … And I’m starting to choke up.”
!
_The Naeem Khan gown Malia Obama wore._
What might have also made Obama choke up was looking at the price of his daughters’ dresses. While their...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Yahoo News aggregates content from various sources, including reputable news outlets. However, it's primarily a news aggregator rather than a direct source of original reporting. Given its mixed reputation in terms of uncovering misinformation, it may not always provide the most stringent fact-checking.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the cost of Sasha and Malia Obama's dresses at a state dinner, specifically stating that they wore dresses that cost approximately $20,000 each. While it does not state that they cost over $40,000 collectively, it implies that the combined cost does not meet or exceed that threshold. Therefore, it is relevant for determining the truth of the original claim.

evidence1.title: Presidential Daughters Attending State Dinners, Part 1

website_content.content:
by Carl Anthony
on March 20, 2016

Malia Obama (left foreground), followed by her sister Sasha and mother, First Lady Michelle Obama, and behind them Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau as formal guests at the state dinner for the Canadian Prime Minister. (amazingstoriesaroundtheworld.blogspot.com)
Over the last seven years, the White House press corps has become accustomed to being able to closely observe the First Daughters Malia Obama, 17, and Sasha Obama, 14, only during their rare appearances.
The President and his daughters during the 2015 ceremony accepting a Thanksgiving turkey.
The two presidential daughters have been front and center at larger public events like their father’s two presidential inaugurations, the annual children’s festival that is the Easter Egg Roll on the White House South Lawn and ceremonies like the annual acceptance (and pardon) of a Thanksgiving turkey on the North Portico.
Malia Obama at the Canadian state dinner.
The media and, through them, the American public were thus startled to see the two young women dressed in formal gowns and attending a White House state dinner as official guests, on Thursday, March 10, 2016.
The reason for this comparatively rare form of presidential entertaining, under the direction of the First Lady, was to honor another world leader’s child, Justin Trudeau, who followed his father’s path and went on to win his nation’s election as Prime Minister of Canada.
Sasha Obama speaks with Canadian native, actor Ryan Reynolds...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This website focuses specifically on the history and contributions of First Ladies in the United States. While it provides historical information, it might not be as rigorous in fact-checking or reporting on contemporary events involving First Ladies.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source mentions the event where the daughters attended the state dinner, but it does not provide details about the cost of the dresses. Due to this lack of price specificity, the evidence is not very useful for verifying the claim.

metatags.og:description:

During the official White House event last Thursday night welcoming Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, both Sasha and Malia ruled the red carpet, rubbed elbows with dignitaries and enjoyed a rare star-struck moment with “Deadpool” star Ryan Reynolds.

*

Malia, Sasha turn heads at first state dinner
---------------------------------------------
######  | 3/17/2016, 11:43 p.m.
]
Malia and Sasha Obama turned the Cross Hall portico into a fashion catwalk — making a splash in designer gowns at their first state dinner. The First Family welcomed Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and his wife, Sophie Grégoire Trudeau, to the White House. It was the first U.S. visit for a Canadian prime minister in nearly two decades. Photo by Pete Souza
Sasha and Malia Obama, the teenage daughters of President Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama, were nothing less than stunning for their first state dinner, where they were first clad in designer fabrics and later in controversy.
During the official White House event last Thursday night welcoming Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, both Sasha and Malia ruled the red carpet, rubbed elbows with dignitaries and enjoyed a rare star-struck moment with “Deadpool” star Ryan Reynolds.
Unfortunately, heated discussions centering on the girls attire have arisen, marring the First Family’s historic evening. The issue arose when Kristen Sze, an ABC network news anchor in San Francisco, commented about the price of the girls’ gowns.
Ms. Sze called the gowns, which ranged in price from $17,000 to $20,000, “too expensive for such young girls.” She further fueled the discussion by asking her Twitter followers if they would pay that price for dresses for their teenagers.
Black Twitter took to the Twittersphere in defense of the girls, hitting back with comments like, “Better question: Is your mom The First Lady? No? Your opinion is irrelevant.”
The First Family has been characteristically unfazed by the subsequent gown discussion. Joanna Rosholm, press secretary to the First Lady, released this statement in the past about Mrs. Obama’s wardrobe:
“And for the record, the government isn’t paying for any of the first family’s wardrobe. Mrs. Obama pays for her clothing. For official events of public...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Richmond Free Press is a community newspaper known for delivering news and features important to the African American community. It has a good reputation for providing thorough reporting on local matters.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article explicitly mentions that the prices of the dresses were between $17,000 to $20,000 each, pointing towards a total cost of $34,000 for both dresses. While this does not confirm that taxpayers paid over $40,000, it refutes the claim as untrue, as it indicates the cost is below that amount.

website_content.content:
Malia Obama, Sasha Obama make their State Dinner debut in Naeem Khan outfits - The American Bazaar
=============== 
!
!]
Thursday, March 21
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
]
 »  » **Malia Obama, Sasha Obama make their State Dinner debut in Naeem Khan outfits**
Malia Obama, Sasha Obama make their State Dinner debut in Naeem Khan outfits
============================================================================
By March 15, 2016Updated:March 15, 2016  2 Mins Read
]
Share
Obama sisters sported dresses which were under $20,000.
AB Wire
!
The Naeem Khan gown Malia Obama wore
While First Lady Michelle Obama has often sported reasonably priced outfits by the American designer J. Crew, her daughters Malia Obama and Sasha Obama are true royalty in the White House when it comes to expensive brand labels.
At the recently held State Dinner for Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau by President Barack Obama, the Obama daughters made their state-dinner debut, and were the cynosure of all eyes in resplendent dresses by Indian American designer Naeem Khan.
“When I was first elected to this office, Malia was just 10 and Sasha was 7. And they grow up too fast,” the president said during his opening remarks at the eventon Thursday night. “Now Malia is going off to college. … And I’m starting to choke up.”
What might have also made Obama choke up was looking at the price of his daughters’ dresses, reported Yahoo Style. While their mother opted for a custom strapless number from one of her favorite designers, Jason Wu, her daughters went with Naeem Khan.
!
The Naeem Khan gown Sasha Obama wore
Malia, 17, who was seated next to Saturday Night Live’s Lorne Michaels and actress Sandra Oh, wore a strapless faille gown with crystal beading from the pre-fall 2015 collection. The 100 percent silk piece is no longer available for purchase, but it originally retailed for $17,990. The embellished piece didn’t need any more bling, so she went without jewelry. Malia blew out her hair in loose waves and had a subtle cat eye and nude lips, said the report.
While Malia went for a more classic, elegant look, her younger sister added a young, fresh flair. Also in Naeem Khan, Sasha chose a look from the Indian-American...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: American Bazaar Online covers news related to the Indian diaspora in the U.S. While it provides niche content and has a decent level of reporting on specific cultural topics, its overall reliability may not match that of larger, well-established mainstream news outlets.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence provides insights into the cost of the dresses, clearly mentioning their prices which were under $20,000 each. This supports the argument that taxpayers did not pay over $40,000 for the dresses, making it somewhat valuable.

newsarticle.headline: Sasha & Malia Obama: Critics Slam $20,000 State Dinner Dresses

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]... Dinner.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Written by Danielle Clark, HelloBeautiful
Published on March 14, 2016
Share
Share the post
--------------
### Share this link via
### Or copy link
Copy Copied
NewsOne Featured Video
CLOSE
It’s expected that critics will come out of the woodwork whenever the Obamas do something awesome, but it’s always shocking when naysayers criticize the children of public figures.
 and  last week attended their first White House State Dinner with their parents, **** and **First Lady **, to honor Canadian Prime Minister **Justin Trudeau**.
While the First Lady wore a custom **Jason Wu** gown, the girls opted for age-appropriate **Naeem Khan** dresses.
They looked stunning in the dresses loaned to them —key word “loaned”— but somehow naysayers found a problem. The “issue” concerns the fact that their embroidered appliqué gowns cost an estimated $20,000 apiece.
**** magazine noted that the guiding principle seemed to be “princess moment,” as both girls selected super-romantic gowns from the designer’s recent collections.
Malia, 17, chose a simple, sophisticated blush gown with a sweetheart neckline and all over crystal beading, which once retailed on Moda Operandi for $17,990. Sasha, 14, went for something a little bolder, deciding on a beaded lace and appliqué ball gown in shades of cranberry, turquoise, black and beige; it formerly sold for $19,990.
The uproar over the girls’ dresses began after **Kristen Sze**, an ABC News anchor in San Francisco, criticized the First Family in a since-deleted tweet for allowing the girls to wear the expensive dresses. She later apologized:
But it wasn’t deleted before Black Twitter could respond:
It was not the first time the girls have become ensnared in the politics of criticism.
In 2014, they were criticized for wearing short skirts and looking disinterested at the White House Turkey Pardon. _“Act like being in the White House matters to you,”_ GOP staffer Elizabeth Lauten said in a Facebook post. _“Dress like you deserve respect, not a spot at the bar. And certainly don’t make faces at televised, public events.”_
But what’s so interesting is that back in 2001, there was no criticizing from White House staffers when President **George W. Bush**’s 19-year-old .
If there’s one...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: NewsOne aims to provide news stories relevant to the African American community. While it often covers important topics sensitively, it is sometimes criticized for being less rigorous in its fact-checking compared to mainstream outlets.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence states that the dresses cost an estimated $20,000 each, addressing the dress prices directly and confirming that they do not total to over $40,000. It strongly supports the assertion that the claim is false.

website_content.content:
Sasha and Malia Wear Naeem Khan Gowns in the 2016 Obama Family Christmas Card | Teen Vogue
===============
]
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
*   
Sasha and Malia Wear Naeem Khan Gowns in the 2016 Obama Family Christmas Card
=============================================================================
The ultimate clapback.
!
By 
December 9, 2016
Every holiday season, it's tradition that the presidential family sends out a Christmas card to hundreds of thousands of lucky recipients. This year marks the Obamas' last Christmas card as the first family (_tear_) so they really wanted to bring it home in style. They chose an image from the Canada State Dinner this past Spring, when the whole family was dressed to the nines. First Lady Michelle stunned in a strapless dress by Jason Wu while President Obama chose a classic tuxedo.  looked resplendent on the arms of their parents, both in gowns by Naeem Khan.
#### Instagram content
This content can also be viewed on the site it  from.
Around the time the photo was taken, Malia and Sasha's $17,990 and $19,990 (respectively) gowns caused a bit of a controversy. A news anchor in San Fransisco criticized the price tag — and some conservative media outlets even claimed the gowns were purchased using tax payer dollars. It was a facetious claim, considering that most industry insiders are well aware that political figures — including Michelle Obama, Hillary Clinton and Melania Trump — either purchase their clothing with their own money, or wear it on loan from a designer. As the White House press department later explained, in Sasha and Malia's case, the dresses were indeed on loan from the designer. The media outrage was completely unwarranted — and by immortalizing their looks in this year's Christmas card, the Obama girls certainly had the last laugh. In fact, it may be the classiest comeback ever.
With this card, they inspire us to remember the State Dinner as a special moment for their family, and a perfectly appropriate occasion for gowns of that caliber. At the end of the day, we can only sum this card up with one word: iconic.

]
 is a journalist and the author of “Worn Out: How Our Clothes Cover Up Fashion’s...[Content truncated]

It has been recognized for its investigative pieces and reporting on contemporary political matters.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: It provides the specific cost for each dress, which emphasizes that their dressing costs do not surpass the claimed amount. This evidence is quite relevant for refuting the claim.

 • 
Reporter Comments on Cost of Malia and Sasha’s State Dinner Dresses, Internet Schools Her
=========================================================================================
Dear Kristin Sze, you picked the wrong first daughters to mess with.
!
Sasha and Malia State Dinner
!
By  · 
When pictures surfaced of Malia and Sasha Obama attending their first State Dinner last Thursday evening, everyone had the same reaction: they looked beautiful. That’s everyone except a San Francisco ABC news anchor. Kristen Sze took to Twitter to share her disdain for the hefty price tag of Sasha’s gorgoeus gown. Soon after Sze’s tweet, both her mentions and the timeline were full of reactions on her completely unneccessary commentary. ****
> Better question: Is your mom The First Lady? No? Well, STFU, your opinion is irrelevant. https://t.co/5QwG68vAv6
> 
> — Disney Villain (@carlettaisgreat) 
> Is Sasha Obama, a whole president’s daughter, supposed to wear a Children’s Place dress to the State Dinner because she’s 14?
> 
> — clyde davis (@thefentybarb) 
> The teens we’d want to represent America, Sasha & Malia, go to ONE fancy dinner, in 8 years, wearing a fancy dress, and it’s a problem.
> 
> — Melissa & Stuff (@fabglance1)...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Essence, aimed primarily at African American women, stands out for providing in-depth features and articles. With a strong commitment to accuracy and a long-standing reputation in the industry, it has a solid track record in research and journalistic integrity.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source directly addresses criticisms regarding the cost of the dresses, confirming their individual prices and noting they were on loan. It effectively supports countering the claim that taxpayers paid over $40,000.

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Facebook is a social media platform where content can be widely shared without rigorous fact-checking. Tabloids, fake news, and reputable journalism coexist on this platform, making it an unreliable source for verifying information.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This is largely irrelevant as it does not discuss the dresses, their costs, or the issue stated in the claim. It provides no context to determine the authenticity of the claim.
